page.title: 07 Local History_Bogroy
page.content: A popular landmark is Bogroy Inn which has been closely associated with smugglers in the not so distant past. Until the end of the 19th century illicit whisky distilling appears to have been fairly prevalent in the Inverness district. As long as the smuggler evaded the detection from customs officers, whisky making was quite profitable. A quarter of barley cost about a pound to purchase but many of these clandestine distilleries grew their own crops. From a quarter of grain they obtained about 50 gallons of whisky. It sold at 18 shillings a gallon ,a considerable difference from present day rates. Of course the whisky was drunk by the community themselves which lead to a considerable amount of squalor and drunkeness.
